revisions.rev:
This is a list of albums associated with the manga and anime series ''[[Zetsuai 1989]]'', its [[dojinshi]] prequel ''Dokusen Yoku'' and its sequel ''Bronze: Zetsuai Since 1989''. The albums were released between 1988 and 1996.
==Calekka== {{Infobox Album <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Albums --> | Name = Calekka | Type = Soundtrack | Artist = [[Shinichi Ishihara]], [[Suzuki Hiroaki]], [[Tsubakura Yuiko]] | Released = {{Start date|1988|11|6}} | Recorded = {{flagicon|Japan}} | Genre = [[anime soundtrack]] | Length = 38 min | Label = [[EMI Music Japan|Toshiba-EMI]] | Producer = | Reviews = | Last album = | This album = | Next album = }}{{nihongo|'''Calekka Original Album'''|å½¼çç« ãªãªã¸ãã«ã¢ã«ãã }}, sometimes called '''Karekka''', is a music album, released on November 6, 1988<ref>1989 may appear in other sources, but 1988 is stated on the [http://www.kreuz-net.com official website] of [[Minami Ozaki]].</ref> and dedicate to [[yaoi]] [[doujinshi]] series {{nihongo|''Dokusen Yoku''|ç¬å æ¬²}}. ''Dokusen Yoku'' or ''Desire to Monopolize''<ref>You may find other variants of translation, such as: Desire of Absolute Possession, Possessive Desires and etc.</ref> were published under the CLUB DOLL circle and it was one of the longest series by [[Minami Ozaki]], the creator of [[Zetsuai 1989]]. The yaoi line is developed between Kojiro Hyuga and Ken Wakashimazu, [[Association football|football players]] from [[Captain Tsubasa]] anime and manga.
The album mostly consists of songs performed by [[Japanese people|Japanese]] singers [[Suzuki Hiroaki]], [[Tsubakura Yuiko]] and [[Shinichi Ishihara]]. It also contains one [[Drama CD]] track and two instrumental tracks.

'''"Bad Blood"''', performed by [[Hayami Show]], was also released as [[Single (music)|single]] album on October 14, 1992. It consists of four tracks: #BAD BLOOD â 03:58 #SWEET SLAUGHTER â 04:26 #BAD BLOOD ''-[[karaoke]] version-'' â 03:58 #SWEET SLAUGHTER ''-karaoke version-'' â 04:26
==Zetsuai DramaMix 1993== ''Zetsuai DramaMix 1993'' â music album and [[Drama CD]], based on five ''Zetsuai 1989'' manga volumes. Album was released on January 29, 1992, together with the first ''Bronze'' [[manga]] [[tankÅbon|volume]].

==Bronze Original Soundtrack== {{Infobox album| <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Albums --> | Name = Bronze Original Soundtrack | Type = Soundtrack | Artist = [[Hayami Show]], [[Inoue Takehide]] | Cover = | Background = | Released = December 18, 1996 | Recorded = {{flagicon|Japan}} | Genre = [[Anime soundtrack]] | Length = | Label = [[Victor Entertainment]] | Producer = | Reviews = | Last album = | This album = | Next album = }} {{nihongo|BRONZE zetsuai since 1989 original soundtrack|BRONZE zetsuai since 1989 ãªãªã¸ãã«ãµã¦ã³ããã©ãã¯}} â original soundtrack for the second [[OVA]] â [[Bronze: Zetsuai since 1989|Bronze]], released on December 18, 1996 under [[Victor Entertainment]]<ref>[[Japanese language|Japanese]]: ãã¯ã¿ã¼ã¨ã³ã¿ãã¤ã³ã¡ã³ã</ref> label. The singers are [[Hayami Show]] and [[Inoue Takehide]] (credited as TAKEHIDE). ''"Bronze â End"'', sometimes called ''"Bronze -Final Chapter-"'', is the [[Anime|ending theme]] of ''Bronze'' [[OVA]].
